displayed_text: Patient: I’m so - I’ve seen it. I’ve seen it… Doctor: Okay. Yeah, this’ll be… Patient: …and I’ve had it so if that makes more sense for you… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …go for it. Doctor: Thank you. I think you know when you have stuff in the in the belly though we don’t like to open you up unless we have to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it will create more scarring and that’s a different thing than the prostate. Patient: I had none from that da Vinci procedure. Doctor: We will, we will get in, we will get out with these samples, done. Now you know anytime we poke there’s always a downside because you’re poking… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …bleeding, infection, you could pop something, uh admission, any of the above. So… Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But when you’re on pills like that, experimental ones – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You don’t want to have some big surgery, be scheduled in the middle of it. Doesn’t make sense. Because you have to do one at a time. Patient: I got you. Doctor: Because it’s a big sur – I mean it’s a big one. (Cell phone rings) Patient: So let me ask you this here, doc. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Do people come out of that surgery? Doctor: Oh, yeah! They do! (Cell phone rings) Patient: Right. Doctor: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this –

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …I don’t think it’ll happen. The radiology guys will go over that. Um from a research standpoint, we hang onto your stuff. If any point in time you’re like (pfft) Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …Otherwise we literally try to maximize as much information as possible from your stupid cancer. Patient: Well as I as I said, if… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …if, if it’s anywhere, if it’s, if it’s the same people that did the port if it’s people that as are as competent as the people that did the port, I have no problem with it at all. Doctor: Yeah. They do it all day long which is terrific. Patient: Because it was not, I mean it wss - it was a not, it was a total non-event. In and out, it was a total non-event. Doctor: Yeah. I agree. That’s that’s wonderful. Okay okay, sit tight here. I’m gonna have M____ come in. Patient: Alright. Doctor: She’s gonna harass you anyways. And then afterwards if we have other questions we’ll we’ll chit-chat some more. Patient: I would appreciate it if you would have your nutrition people take a look.

Patient: Uh I try not to do that. Family Member 1: Yeah. What about using their toilet? See what I’m saying, while he’s there. Doctor: So same thing, I would just bring a pair of gloves, your own towels and then you wipe and just get a bag that you throw off the stuff. You know what's hard is toddlers get into everything. And you just can't help it. They're curious. Family Member 1: Well, it wouldn't be just for the toddler. Like we all use the main bathroom. There's the upstairs. She's still in diapers, so she has where she not trained yet. Okay, but myself the one that you come in the door, I can't keep climbing the stairs and using the bathroom. Right? And that he has to discipline he still has to disinfect, right? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. So you you get one of those Clorox thingy that you pull out. Patient: Yeah. I know. Family Member 1: At the hospital. Doctor: You can get food gloves if you want, you know? Family Member 1: Yeah we have hospital gloves. Family Member 2: And then put them in a bag. Doctor: That's it. Patient: Yeah nothing complicated.

Patient: And he’s said he’s had good luck with other patients that have had pain with that Cymbalta. Doctor: In the joints? I mean I don’t know how it will help with that with your pain, but you know what it’s definitely worth a try. I have no objections to giving that a try but I’m not terribly hopeful, but if he’s seen something different in his experience. Patient: Well if that’s the case I’ll just stay on the prednisone. Forget that. I mean it’s not something Doctor: Okay I mean I’m okay if you want to give that a try Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: and there’s no objection or problem - Patient: Okay. Doctor: from the study standpoint. Patient: Alright, Okay. Family Member: Which is the lesser of the two evils as far as taking it long term? I’m not familiar with Cymbalta. Doctor: Well, I think Cymbalta is probably you know much more proven you know long term. The steroids can have other issues of you know blocking the immune systems likely increased risk of infections and things like that over the long term, but you know it’s – I kind of think it’s unlikely that it will help arthritic pain. If it is neuropathic nerve pain and stuff, you know Cymbalta can be effective. Patient: Yeah I think that’s what he said also yeah. Doctor: I don’t think that is the reason for your pain, but that’s my impression.

Patient: I like - Uh yeah. Doctor: Okayy. Patient: I’m actually looking at the screen. Um… Doctor: Okay. This is – you’re gonna be wore out. Patient: Dr___, Dr____ Doctor: I think you’re gonna be a little bit more out… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …than that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. But you need a driver and so you know we have to get, yeah. Patient: I don’t know if I get one by tomorrow. Doctor: You probably can’t and they probably can’t do it tomorrow.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. It comes with side effects because it’s never nothing without nothing. Patient: What is the side effects? Doctor: Number one, two and three is tiredness. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great. Patient: Just physically tired? Doctor: Physically tired and it’s a weirder tired not like you worked out in the yard for twelve hours and can’t do much, it’s just no get up and go. If that happens, we take a break and we reduce the medicine dose. Patient: Let me ask you something doc. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Can we, can we provide a pill that would give me a little, like a vitamin that would give me a little energy? Doctor: No I think the issue of you not having as much energy is that your cancer is starting to, sorry that your thing is starting to break through slowly, Patient: Right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I thought you’d like that. Downside if you have to be here all the time. It’s three times a week. Can you imagine vitamin C flitters outta your system. Patient: It does. Doctor: So this is a J___ study that we’re hoping to open within the next… Doctor: …Yeah, probably within the next month. Patient: Neither one of you know what the term ‘really old’ means. Doctor: That’s true. That’s true. Patient: Thank you. (laughs) Doctor: Um but that’s an option where… Patient: I’m working on year seventy-four so I’m hanging in there. Doctor: Doing pretty darn good. Um but I think the the downside of that trial is you’re here all the time, but the plus side is you’re getting you know the chemo is a standard and the vitamin C we’ll see what happens so. Patient: Yeah. If I need to cancel that trip… Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -that's not what we want. Patient: Do I throw away? Doctor: No, no no no. Don't go throw anything. We'll take your leftovers, but at the moment just keep it in case we need to come back to it this year. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don't, don't do anything. Family Member: Okay. Patient: What about the finasteride I'm still on? Doctor: That's okay. Because you've been taking that for your pee and you’re just being- Patient: I don’t know what’s the other one. Family Member: So okay. Patient: Finasteride and folic acid, we're the only other ones I was taking. Family Member: There's no reason why you can't you take calcium with vitamin nuts.

Patient: Because it’s – Doctor: It’s connected! Patient: Connected, and then it’ll still be goin’ in the pad, and if it go – Doctor: So, I’m sayin’ – Patient: In that pad in that area. Doctor: I know you. I would rather that you know there’s a potential of two bags. Patient: Well then – Doctor: And then we think about what’s necessary. Patient: That’s what the, the doctor at P_ said. Doctor: I know! Patient: He say, he say – Doctor: I talked to that doctor, remember?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I ain’t gotta take no shots, no hip shots, or Doctor: You are due for your Lupron. So, Patient: Which one is that? Doctor: The hormone. The Lupron shot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So, let me see if you want. Do you want to do it today? Patient: I mean Doctor: You can go over and do it. Patient: What? Doctor: To the treatment area.

Patient: If, if, if, if – Doctor: So, if the hormones alone are making those get better, better, better, we give you the trial, I have no way to know did it do anything. So, we usually wait until the hormone stops working by itself. Family Member: And, that’s all just gauged by a PSA or do you do the – Doctor: It’s gauged by PSA as a screening and then, you know, at some point we would then just re-image you, too. Family Member: Hmm. Doctor: But, our experience is, as long as the PSA’s going down, usually the imaging is either getting better or staying stable. So. Patient: If the PSA is that reliable in terms of – Doctor: Ehhh, it’s reliable enough. I don’t know, it’s not unbelievably reliable, but Patient: But, if – Doctor: Rather than, you know, trying to give you a CAT scan every month. Patient: It’s, it’s, it’s unlikely that the PSA is going to go up if things are okay. Doctor: Yes.

Patient: Yeah I was. Doctor: So they had to give you a lot of fluids. So your doctor’s pretty, pretty worried. Your, your lungs, you know, they’re already not great with the cancer but then you had pneumonia on top of that, so. Well, we’ll get those records to make sure that’s, and you know, kind of what ended up happening because they couldn’t give me anything until you were discharged. So now that you’re discharged for a couple of days, they’ll send that up, up to us. Patient: Yeah, Uh the last time they gave me something to take home, antibiotics, some kind of antibiotics to take home, that just I didn’t get nothing. Doctor: Okay. You didn’t get some this time? Okay. So it might have been more flu. Yeah. Okay. So, I’ll, I’ll have M___ come in and say hello and then we’ll have you come back here in a couple of weeks and let’s, let’s run through it. Awesome. Glad you’re back. You scared me. Doctor: You take care of him. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I’ll have her come in and we’ll, we’ll get you out of here. Alright. I’ll see you guys. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Don’t do that in the morning, do it – do it at… Doctor: Right. Patient: …dinner or don’t it at dinner. Doctor: When was the last time you saw the integrative medicine folks at B_____? Patient: Ahhh a year ago. Doctor: Okay. I mean it wouldn’t hurt to go back. Now obviously… Patient: Yeah but I want your opinion. Doctor: No no, I’m I’m happy to do that. As we move on to other drugs though… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …we will have to reevaluate that… Patient: That’s fine. Doctor: Because there’s interactions potential. Okay. Patient: Right. That’s why –
